citation.article-title: Characterization of 'Candidatus Neoehrlichia lotoris' (family Anaplasmataceae) from raccoons (Procyon lotor).
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: ‘Candidatus Neoehrlichia lotoris’ [lo.tor′is. L. gen. n. lotoris of a clothes-washer, of Procyon lotor (a raccoon)]. The reference strain is RAC413R. Isolated from a captive raccoon experimentally infected with ‘Candidatus N. lotoris’ by blood inoculation from a naturally infected raccoon from Clarke Co., Georgia, USA (Munderloh et al., 2007). Not infectious to two strains of laboratory mice (Mus musculus, strains BALB/c and C3H), laboratory rats (Rattus norvegicus, Wistar strain) or laboratory rabbits (Oryctolagus cuniculus, New Zealand White) in limited inoculation trials (Yabsley et al., 2008a). Host cells within raccoons are not known. Morphology of organisms in ISE6 tick cells is similar to that of other members of the family Anaplasmataceae. Member of the family Anaplasmataceae based on 16S rRNA gene, groESL and gltA sequences and growth within membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles. Organisms are Gram-negative, highly pleomorphic (compact coccus-like and elongated, wavy forms; 0.5–4 μm), stain light to dark purple with Giemsa and tend to cluster on the side of the endosome nearest the host cell nucleus. Ultrastructurally, the organism has an outer unit membrane separated from the inner cell wall by a thin periplasmic space, characteristic of the family Anaplasmataceae. In some cases, individual bacteria are wrapped in two sets of membranes. Analysis of the 16S rRNA gene sequence revealed a novel 2 bp insertion compared with members of the genus Ehrlichia (AT at base 784 of E. chaffeensis ArkansasT; GenBank accession no. AF416764). Analysis of gltA sequence revealed a novel deletion compared with members of the genera Ehrlichia and Anaplasma (6 bp deletion at base 1011 of E. chaffeensis ArkansasT; GenBank accession no. AF304142) and a 2 bp insertion compared with other members of the family Anaplasmataceae (TTG at base 744 of E. chaffeensis ArkansasT; AF304142). The G+C content of four sequenced genes of ‘Candidatus N. lotoris’ RAC413R is 38.1 mol%. Can be differentiated from ‘Candidatus N. mikurensis’ on the basis of unique 16S rRNA gene, groESL and gltA sequences.
